Good review, though I can never decide whether I like Exile or Sticky Fingers better.  I agree with those who called out Gram Parsons' contribution to the sound on Exile -- wouldn't have happened without him.

Nice review. Sure I disagree with some of what Mr. Ratliff says, but he obviously cares for the record and has dissected it nicely for us to chew on.  (That said, glad we agree on Ventilator Blues and Just Wanna See His Face which are, for me, the center of the record.)  Exile is too loose and jangly to qualify as a Sgt. Peppers style masterpiece (the same could be said of much of Bob Dylan's output), but that's what makes it such a great listen for me.  It is a mess, but it has always sounded like an honest one.  That Mick and Keith look at it differently is sweet - let's be thankful for the tension between the two and for all that that tension has created over the years.

I saw the Stones for the first time on July 25 1972 at the 'breakfast show' --1.00pm-- at MSG. When I walked in all I could think of was "Mick Jagger, Mick Jagger", but when I walked out, all I was thinking was "Mick Taylor, Mick Taylor". His guitar playing was phenomenal and lyrically soared over the awesome rhythm section of Richards/Wyman/Watts, buttressed by Bobby Keys, Jim Price, and Nicky Hopkins. Mick Jagger's singing and dancing was exemplary, focused, and inspiring. All in all, this was the greatest concert I ever saw, and at $6.50 a ticket, a bargain. To see most of Exile performed live at the time of its issue was the greatest rock and roll experience of my lifetime. Although Let It Bleed and Beggars Banquet were more polished 'studio' albums, Exile was for me the true essence of the Stones.

Exile is IMHO the BEST Stones album of their repertoire.
The diversity of the music is awesome, more so against the backdrop of their
real-life tax woes, the reason for their Exile...

Rivals maybe close only by Sticky Fingers.....

enjoy...the DVD is awesome too

Mr. Ratliff knows how to write about music, a contemporary but he
maybe one of the best ever. I saw the Fallon version of Stones in Exile, all I have to say is I want to be a Rock Star. This is what being a cool rock star was all about. Sheryl Crow said it best "we all want(ed)to be there with them in France, I know I would have been there". When the 8 year old is designated as the "joint roller" for the entire house, you know it's a Rolling Stone party....
That's where I got off. The album of transition, professionalism taking over inspiration. Didn't listen again for three decades... and realized it's the "Will The Circle Be Unbroken" of Rock.

The Democrats ignored the economy and the financial industry all last year. Instead, as we slipped into a deep recession, the Democrats, with a veto proof situation instead took care of their special interests and argued for months about a health care bill. Despite their claims to the contrary, not one Republican vote was needed to pass the law, and no Republican ideas were included. Democrats nonetheless, wasted months getting something passed that few voters wanted. Now suddenly, with midterm elections approaching, Democrats have realized that the economy is the major issue. Republicans will cleverly stall measures that reduce unemployment and fix the economy until very late summer. Then a comprehensive bill will be passed. They will overwhelmingly support it. They will claim credit for it, perhaps rightly so, because it will and it must, include many of their ideas. Then "the party of no" will use that moniker to their advantage: No legalizing all persons who are illegally in the US, No welfare or health care benefits for illegals, No anchor baby citizenship,  No reduction in medicare benefits, No huge medical malpractice settlements which cost consumers money, No requirements that everyone buy health insurance, No restriction on interstate sales of health insurance, No ignoring millions of unemployed by extolling phony job creation programs, No ineffective mortgage foreclosure programs. The "party of no" may have a plan. The Democrats know this and that high unemployment and a stagnant economy will be blamed on their veto proof Congress. How can they, who were in power,convince the millions who have lost jobs, savings, and homes that the Republicans were the cause? How will they convince voters that they did not lie about the costs of the health care bill when the Congressional Budget Office revised upwards the amount by over 100 billion dollars? How will they blame the costs on Republicans? How will they even account for the expense of troops still being in Iraq more than 16 months after Obama took office and Guantanamo's prison still being open? These are things they and the President promised and completely control. The situation seems hopeless and time is running out.

Demographics is NOT driving this shortage--it's a lack of political will to fund necessary public services. Starting in 1981 Americans have been told over and over that their taxes are too high (they're actually lower now than at any time since the mid-'40s) and that they shouldn't have to fund via taxes any service they don't use directly. After 30 years of that philosophy, here we are. People are abandoning their underwater houses and properties as well as their foreclosed houses and the tax base is drying up. The only solution anyone has any political will for is cutting services. Our parents and grandparents (I'm 55) would've coughed up the money--indeed, they DID cough up the money in their day. Now, when it's our turn, instead of protecting and building education, our generation turns around, stares the non-voting children in the eye and says "Too bad--no money for you," and then goes on to fight the regulation of the financial derivative mess that got us here in the first place. The self-serving arrogant stupidity is....I don't know the words that can encompass it. We're doomed. Not figuratively, either.

There are still a lot of kids to be educated, there are still schools with too many kids in each classroom, I'm sure we actually need all of these (new) teachers.
Problem is, we have no money to hire new teachers. We're still paying oh so dearly for the overseas war that is just not ending anytime soon.
As a button once says, "You think education is expensive? Try ignorance."
We've already started to pay for our ignorance now, and it's just going to get worst.

The editorial supports the bill's denial of people's right to refuse to purchase medical insurance and to pay their own bills directly. If insurance premiums are really cheaper than direct payments, everyone would buy medical insurance.

The bill recognizes that people have figured out that they're better off without insurance and seeks to use the IRS to enforce the mandate. Washington knows better than us what's best for us.

Oh, baloney. This bill is an unprecedented expansion of government power, and the Constitutional challengers are absolutely right. Let government stick to "tax and spend" if the "public good" is at issue. To fine someone because they're breathing, with no nexus to commercial activity (remember, "interstate commerce"?) would be heinous.

Besides, the whole concept of this "reform" is inside out. We should not be forcing overpriced insurance down the universal throat; we should be cutting the middleman out entirely (insurance, which brings zero value-added to the medical equation).

We have four good years to get this right: repeal this dim-witted and unconstitutional hamburger of a bill, and enact real reform. Yay for every single one of those 20 states with the guts to say "it doesn't fly". (And how much is *that* litigation costing taxpayers, that we shouldn't have been forced to spend?) Obama was an expensive mistake.

I would think that after SCOTUS showed how legal insanity could undermine the rights of citizens that NYT would be less willing to condone slippery legal tactics to defend a bill to force American citizens to buy a private company product.  This reform should have been done constitutionally by creating a Medicare buy in available to all.  It still can be.  Let's hope the bill is declared unconstitutional so real recorm can take place.

Reglamento de la Ley General de Poblacion — the General Law on Population enacted in Mexico in April 2000, which mandates that federal, local and municipal police cooperate with federal immigration authorities in that country in the arrests of illegal immigrants.

Under the Mexican law, illegal immigration is a felony, punishable by up to two years in prison. Immigrants who are deported and attempt to re-enter can be imprisoned for 10 years. Visa violators can be sentenced to six-year terms. Mexicans who help illegal immigrants are considered criminals.

The law also says Mexico can deport foreigners who are deemed detrimental to "economic or national interests," violate Mexican law, are not "physically or mentally healthy" or lack the "necessary funds for their sustenance" and for their dependents.
